DataElement.preferredName: Parietal Pleura Surgical Margin Involvement Ind-3
DataElement.preferredDefinition: a yes/no indicator to ask if malignant cells are present at the edge of tissue removed from the parietal boundary of the pleura in cancer surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to an observed presence of malignant cells at the edge of tissue removed from the parietal boundary of the pleura in cancer surgery.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: No value exists.:The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.

Concepts.definition: The outermost of the two pleural membranes. It consists of a thin basal layer of fibrous tissue upon which sits a continuous layer of mesothelial cells. The cells function to secrete the lubricant lining the pleural cavity.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Property.preferredDefinition: To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Concepts.definition: To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.
